comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
What a beauty! (and The Beast !) From - www.bruzelius.info/Nautica/Ships/Fourmast_ships/Lyderhorn(1892).html -
A four-masted steel barque built in 1892 by T.R. Oswald & Co., Milford Haven. Dimensions: 94,84×12,90×7,74 meters [311'2×42'4×25'5], tonnage: 2914 GRT and 2723 NRT. 1892 June Launched at the shipyard of T.R. Oswald & Co., Milford Haven, for J.R. De Wolf & Son, Liverpool. 1910 August 13 Sold to Knöhr & Burchard, Hamburg, and was renamed Jersbek. 1914 Interned at Corral, Chile. 1921 Returned to Europe and handed over to the French Government as war damage compensation. 1922 Hulk at Gibraltar.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Can anyone figure out where this is?  Balmain?

comment.author: 33751865@N05
comment._content: Exceptional shot. Congrats on the Explore.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Explore! Mr Hall would have been pleased! Found it! From that "A. S. N. Hotel" (see note), which is mentioned in Trove as John and Mill Streets, Pyrmont (selling tobacco without a licence). The LYDERHORN is anchored in Pyrmont Bay, with Pyrmont in the background. We are looking almost west from about the "R" in Darling on this 1895 interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm3443-sd&rgn=... A stone's throw from the ANMM, but almost unrecognizable to what is there now - the area has probably been rebuilt two or three times.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I think this wonderful photo is in the 1890s, possibly this visit in 1897, when the LYDERHORN brought "one of the largest cargoes of lumber ever shipped to Sydney" (from Chemainus, Canada) - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/14095238. The ship looks unladen (see the waterline), and in good condition / newish compared to these photos - handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/12178 , handle.slv.vic.gov.au/10381/14178 From Trove it seems the LYDERHORN didn't visit Sydney very often - more Newcastle NSW and South Australian ports. Here is news of her hulking (as the JERSBEK) in 1922 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/23528421 The buildings at Pyrmont (amazingly unrecognizable) also suggest 1890s. The area was about to undergo massive development with railways along the foreshore and huge grain wharfs at Darling Island, just to the right of frame. See comments on this 1904 photo - [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw/4580719852/] Development of Pyrmont also seen on this great 1903 panorama looking the other way (east) from the top of the new Pyrmont Powerhouse chimney, which would have shown up in the LYDERHORN photo - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=412343

comment.author: 110421195@N07
comment._content:
Anyone who knows how the ship got it's name...?
Lyderhorn is a mountain west of Bergen, Norway, a very known landmark for sailors arriving from south towards Bergen, the  characteristic silhuett is easy to spot, for a long distance.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/110421195@N07] I have no idea, but you might find something here in the information about the original owners, J.R. De Wolf & Son, Liverpool. Maybe a Norwegian connection ... en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Ratchford_DeWolf guweb2.gonzaga.edu/~dewolf/perry/Pg93-138.pdf
